    # Mariano Guerra 2019-09-17 01:21
    just a word clarification: even if what you are building is free you will have to "sell" it
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-09-17 01:16
    We are asking a lot from our customers. We are asking them to spend hours a day in a new and unfamiliar application, to give up on years or even decades of experience using email for work communication (and abandon all kinds of ad hoc workflows that have developed around their use of email). We are asking them to switch a model of communication which defaults to public; it is an almost impossibly large ask. Almost.
    To get people to say yes to a request that large, we need to (1) offer them a reward big enough to justify their effort and (2) do an exceptional, near-perfect job of execution.
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-09-17 01:12
    the word selling may be another taboo around here too...
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-09-17 01:12
    what are you selling that is not a bag of cool features?
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-09-17 01:12
    this topics seems to be taboo around here so I post it on random: https://medium.com/@stewart/we-dont-sell-saddles-here-4c59524d650d
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-09-14 13:31
    https://twitter.com/eugenewei/status/1119996031322611713?s=21 turns out there’s a good security case for making tools more fun
    1 comments
    # Tom Lieber 2019-09-10 12:50
    Is anyone aware of a data structure that supports SQL-like operations on bags such as projection, selection, and join? I wrote something in Java patterned vaguely on Guava's Table interface, but my first crack at the API was too unreadable to actually submit. :sweat_smile: The important part for me was that it had a join that was implemented as the application of an arbitrary mapping function (input row → 0 or more values for the new column).
    9 comments

    # Garth Goldwater 2019-08-30 18:10
    excel is the only product i can think of that achieved both market dominance and (i’d argue) a primary goal of the projects in this slack: to enable ordinary people to trudy their knowledge and fundamentally change the world without having to think very much about what a computer is at all
    # Wouter van Oortmerssen 2019-08-30 12:26

    # Wouter van Oortmerssen 2019-08-30 12:25
    http://strlen.com/treesheets/
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-30 11:28
    I would argue that AirTable is an entirely different kind of product than a spreadsheet, which is a very specific tool like a hammer. I view AirTable as a collaborative database with various modules, some of which resemble spreadsheets. One could argue that it is merger of those two worlds (spreadsheet and database) that has not been seen much since the very old Framework product that Robert Carr wrote in the 80's. Framework got so hot they did TV advertising for it; when was the last time you saw a TV commercial for consumer software?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-30 11:23
    For competitors off the top of my head there's Google Sheets, Airtable, OpenOffice, iWork Numbers, any other big ones?
    # Chris Granger 2019-08-30 11:21
    Airtable is doing very well as a mishmash of Excel and Access
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-30 11:18
    Between the twin jaws of "free" (google), and pushed by 500+ billion dollar market cap company (MS), no competing product has any chance of surviving. Only crumbs left.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-30 11:18
    I've never used Excel very much, but one of the things that's always intrigued me about it is that it has base of very passionate users. It feels like a product many people truly enjoy using, there aren't a lot of software products that genuinely garner affection in that way
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-30 11:16
    One should always distinguish between popularity and actual merit. Van Gogh sold one painting in his life.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-30 11:16
    This has probably been discussed before here, but I'd love to hear any recommendations from people here for the spreadsheet state of the art today
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-30 11:16
    And a considerable part of Excel's success is due to marketing prowess and the overwhelming power of Microsoft. There have been many innovative products superior to Excel in different ways that never got much traction.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-30 11:15
    Excel is a very successful product, but it isn't perfect, and there were many innovations on the way that have not received proper credit. Excel is now a fairly bloated product and i think successive versions are getting harder to use. The spreadsheet does have many fundamental features worth copying, and i have done so in my Beads language: 1) protected, extended arithmetic 2) automatic natural order of recalculation/refresh, 3) no object creation, all things already exist already, they just might not have a value yet
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-30 10:44
    https://blog.stephsmith.io/history-of-excel/

    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 12:25
    One funny bit on search in general is it's really weird to me that code editors often don't show results live when you start typing (e.g., like Google does). That feels like it should be a table stakes feature in 2019. Even more so when doing a find and replace. Having to hit enter to see whether I performed the replace correctly (instead of just seeing the transformation live) feels anachronistic
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 12:21

    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:33
    @Kartik Agaram To address your concerns, I've tried to keep move the discussion from implementation details of individual tiling wms to advantages inherent in the model. If there's a better way to do that, I'm happy to hear it. You already mentioned giving more back story in the beginning, which is feedback I'll factor in (although I was concerned about making a wall of text right of the bat).
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 10:32
    i3 in particular was very little customization away from stock for me, and I appreciate that.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:30
    Shrug, I'm neutral on shortcuts, some people like them some don't. I was under the impression one of the reason people like tiling wms is they like the shortcuts. So I was curious how well those same shortcuts work with a stacking wm, from my perspective they seem to work well. Again we're totally in personal preference territory here, see Tog https://www.asktog.com/TOI/toi06KeyboardVMouse1.html
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 10:28
    I'm very conscious that my particular set of choices is some kind of local maxima
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 10:27
    if I notice something repetitive, it might inspire me to find a better way
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 10:26
    as an emacs user, I don't learn 100x as many shortcuts as I do
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 10:26
    more shortcuts is worse in isolation, but it can be a net win depending on usage
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:24
    Why aren't tiling wm shortcuts a burden? These are just preferences, some people like resizing with the mouse, some with shortcuts, live and let live
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 10:23
    I'd call it being burdened with more shortcuts.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:22
    @Tom Lieber I would say I just get more shortcuts with a stacking wm, I wouldn't call it anything new. I don't see any distinction between what I do with a stacking wm and configuring a tiling wm
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 10:21
    The allure of your AppleScript was that somebody else (i.e. you) has already done the messing about for me.
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 10:20
    @Roben Kleene The very fact that you're replacing a window manager with an automation app suggests to me that you're not appreciating people's arguments here. Sure I could make stacking WMs do anything I want with a Turing-complete scripting language. That's not because of the stacking WM, it's because of the Turing-complete language.

    Tiling WMs reduce the amount people need to mess with their WM. Adding a new way to mess with the WM doesn't address that advantage.
    # Tom Lieber 2019-08-27 10:19
    When you replicate it, do you end up with something that's more like a tiling wm than what you started with, or do you end up somewhere new?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:11
    Always excluding the inherent difference about the stacking or tiling itself, which I recognize as an advantage
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:10
    @Tom Lieber Yeah I 100% agree, I just haven't been able to come up with an example myself that proves that. Every attempt I've tried I've been able to replicate with a stacking wm with no downside
    # Tom Lieber 2019-08-27 10:10
    Being easier to use with a keyboard, and easier to configure, do seem to stem directly from having a more constrained layout model (tiling).
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:09
    (but paid)
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:08
    https://www.keyboardmaestro.com/main/
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:08
    I use keyboard meastro now, recommended unconditionally
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:08
    Ha don't use the AppleScript, I couldn't make it fast
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 10:07
    The disconnect may be that people are talking about existing product categories rather than platonic ideals.

    I'm not sure anyone's ever made the claim that what tiling WMs are today strictly dominates what stacking WMs could be in the best of all possible universes. That feels like a strawman.

    Which is why I wish you had led with the product that improves on stacking WM state of the art. I got a lot out of this discussion, but I suspect you'd have gotten more if you'd done that. You'd have needed to repeat yourself less.

    I'm definitely looking forward to trying out your AppleScript.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:04
    (And I'm not saying there aren't advantages to tiling wms automatically resizing other windows, it's just that seems to be a marginal feature to most people compared to the keyboard control and configuration features)
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:03
    Sorry but thing just makes my head want to explode, for years I've been hearing people saying tiling wms are a huge productivity boost and then listing reasons (like easier to use from the keyboard and easier to configure) that have nothing to do with tiling windows. I know I have like some sort of problem that I sometimes drive people crazy pushing points like this, but I'm just trying to makes sure I understand correctly.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 10:00
    But that was my whole point: Most arguments for why people use tiling wms is because they're easier to configure, not because they tile windows.

    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:54

    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:51
    A bit more backstory: There is a nut job wm for macOS called Mjolnir https://github.com/mjolnirapp/mjolnir that I got pretty deep into, and that left me with question: This seems to do all the things that people talk about with tiling wms, but it doesn't actually require any "tiling" features. That was maybe three or four years ago, and I'm still trying to figure it out.

    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:41
    I have used stacking WMs far longer than tiling WMs, but I quickly became more effective with a tiling WM. I think most people are more used to stacking WMs, but some switch to tiling WMs.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:40
    To flip that around: All of these other arguments sound like you've learned to configure a tiling wm, but if you learned to configure a stacking wm, you'd see they are easy in teh model too
    2 comments
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 09:39
    I use stacking WMs but it's useful to understand the trade-offs. Trade-offs involve what's easy vs what's hard. Repeatedly reductively saying "I can do that" closes your mind to that important axis.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:39
    The only hard advantage to tiling wm I've seen is that when you resizing a window, it doesn't hide information in other windows. I'm jsut wondering if there are more advantages.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:38
    If I had an opinion, I'd by listing reasons overlapping windows are better, honestly to me it just seems like personal preference, pros and cons to each
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:38
    Frankly I don't have an opinion as I've never used one
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:37
    Actually I don't think I've argued any specific thing here
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 09:37
    @Roben Kleene it seems like you've already made up your mind :grin:
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:36
    Being able to see all the information I need, so something about relevance and density.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:35
    For use-cases, I mentioned coarse-grained task switching (I'm on C# for a few hours, leave the python for a while), overview vs focus on a single window in a workspace (fullscreen, unfullscreen).
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:34
    I think that explains our impasse a little for me.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:34
    What are the "common use-cases"? I can think of one, that's half/half, e.g., built-in to Windows. Are there others?
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 09:34
    I like the cognitive model of tiling WMs as trees. I wonder if someone has created a tiling WM with zoom in/out operations that go in/out of full screen without changing layout. You can zoom in to a single window, but can you zoom out to take in multiple workspaces?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:34
    I mean fewer shortcuts, but fewer keypresses is also an interesting metric
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:33
    I am happy to learn more shortcuts for fewer keypresses
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:33
    By 'less keyboard shortcuts' do you mean fewer shortcuts, or fewer keypresses over common use-cases?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:31
    And I haven't seen a reason you need less keyboard shortcuts with tiling?
    1 comments
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:31
    Not sure on that, both policies seem equally learnable? Window stacks or window tiles?
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-27 09:30
    My summary after reading this exchange: tiling WMs provide mechanisms for resizing and also a very convenient, learnable default policy. Stacking WMs don't imposed a policy, and so to provide equivalent power in mechanisms need people to learn a lot more shortcuts.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:30
    But with a refactoring tool, it's easy to quantify the advantage: Less key presses to get the same result
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:30
    yea, it's a lot like paredit in lisp for me.
    # Tom Lieber 2019-08-27 09:29
    The way a refactoring tool is more convenient than making all the changes by hand, or the way moving things in a box is more convenient than carrying them one by one? :stuck_out_tongue: Lots of little reasons. I feel like people have touched on most of them already.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:27
    hmm, the actions are more relative to the window you're focused on than that.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:26
    That sounds like the same thing as shortcut for upper left, lower left and right, the tiling WM difference is just that it replaces rather than overlaps
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:25
    Just as I can move windows between workspaces with a hotkey, I can push them into a subcontainer with a different layout just as easily.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:25
    What makes the way they are entangled convenient?
    # Tom Lieber 2019-08-27 09:25
    In a tiling wm, dimensions are entangled in a convenient way. I think someone mentioned that. In Windows, the entanglement breaks really easily. Workspaces seem orthogonal?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:24
    it's just that they are fixed to your screen size and there's usually a fixed number of them.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:24
    I think it's subtle, but think of your workspaces as tiles.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:24
    The tree structure sounds like a cool configuration feature, which sounds great, is there a reason a stacking window manager couldn't have that same feature?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:22
    E.g., on macOS I have a chat workspace, a programming workspace, a media workspace, etc... what's the connection to tiling windows?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:22
    I like to write outlines when I approach everything, so tree structures work for me :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:20
    That sounds like an implementation detail, not an inherent advantage?
    1 comments
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:20
    so it helps you organize by use-case
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:20
    (And just to be clear, when resizing a window, that you don't hide information on other windows, is just a cold hard advantage of tiling window managers, that's exactly the type of thing I'm looking for)
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:20
    Everything is a tree of containers, workspaces are the top level nodes. Containers determine the layout.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:19
    E.g., from my perspective a workspace is just a bucket of windows, don't see how whether they are stacked or tiled windows matters?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:19
    I'm curious about the workspaces thing though, how would you describe the connection to tiling wm and workspaces?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:17
    When you say "you have to experience it" what I hear is "it's what I'm used to" :slightly_smiling_face: Preferences are great, but if I can't articulate what the specific advantage is, I assume it's just that, a preference rather than an advantage
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:15
    Maybe it's a 'you have to experience it' thing
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:14
    how about: Hierarchical tiling WMs just give you more of why you like workspaces?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:13
    And if you have any suggestions to improve this summary, I'd love to hear it: "I prefer when resizing a window that I can still see all the information in the other windows."
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:12
    Cool, yeah this was super helpful, thanks for responding!
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:11
    Browsers work great at mobile size, and work great at full screen laptop size, but are garbage at everything in between
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:11
    Yeah, browsers are the elephant in the room with tiling window managers I feel like. Browsers are just crap at resizing
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:10
    Ok cool, I've gotten a lot out of this, summarizing the conversation I'd say it's something like: I prefer when resizing a window that I can still see all the information in the other windows.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:10
    I guess as a counterpoint to myself, I do use tabs for browsers, because there's too much useless information across 30 windows.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:09
    Oh got it yeah, ok sorry misread
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:09
    not sure what you mean
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:09
    Do you automatically resize windows when you click into them?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:08
    if I resize window 1 to overlap window 2, which I click into window 2, suddenly window 2 is on top of parts of window 1, and I can't see them unless I a) resize again or b) refocus to window 1 again.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:07
    I'm a bit confused about the line "when I change focus, it overlaps and hides some information"? Changing focus doesn't resize itself?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:06
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:06
    i3 also supports tabs within a container, but I never use them
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:05
    Unless I do that, when I change focus, it overlaps and hides some information from the other window until I do one more thing.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:04
    so every resize becomes two resizes?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:04
    Yeah this gets sort of to, my real question, which is why not? :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:03
    right, I just never want to resize one window over top of another
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:03
    It's just whether when you resizing, whether the other windows are also simultaneously resized that distinguishes a tiling window manager
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:03
    When you get that complex it's better to have a shortcut system, rather than shortcuts for a specific size, but I think that's the same between stacking vs. tiling window managers, e.g., there's nothing inherent about tiling windows that makes keyboard-driven resizing easier
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:02
    windows 10 gets pretty close, but it's powerful with hotkeys for resizing and moving windows between workspaces, and also focus follows mouse.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:02
    Shortcuts for upper left, lower left, and right
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 09:01
    Got it, yeah you could do that with a stacking window manager and shortcuts too.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:01
    two vertically stacked terminals on the left, one big more UI-y thing on the right
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 09:00
    something like this
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:59
    And I don't know what the hyphen means in [-][ ]?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:58
    E.g., I would interpret 2 and 1 as [ ][ ][ ], but it sounds like you mean something different?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:58
    PRobably I still don't understand this: "yea, but like I said, it's always 2 and 1, like [-][ ] "
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:57
    Ok I'm still missing something then :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:57
    but then my terminals are needlessly tall and narrow :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:57
    SO [ ] [ ] [ ] is no problem
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:56
    Oh the individual size for each shortcut is customizable
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:56
    left center right is [ ][ ][ ]
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:56
    I think I'm missing something, why doesn't "have a shortcut for left/center/right" cover that?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:55
    with the left column narrower
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:55
    yea, but like I said, it's always 2 and 1, like [-][ ]
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:54
    Just out of curiosity is there a particular point in your workflow that you tend to make that switch?
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:54
    Full screen is easy with a stacking window manager, but vertical vs. horizontal (if you mean swap these three horizontal columns to three horizontal rows), that would be really difficult with stacking window manager
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:52
    the things that are missing for my common case are easy fullscreen toggle for any window, and vertical vs horizontal layout switches.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:51
    Yeah you could just setup a stacking window manager to have a shortcut for left/center/right, how would you compare that to the tiling approach?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:50
    two on top of each other on the left, and narrow, and one big one on the right
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:50
    I think I prefer 3 windows per workspace
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:50
    I happen to do half and half, but you cna configure any way you want
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:50
    Yeah particular configurationss aren't important
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:49
    I never do half and half
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:49
    Just to push further, I have it setup so I can resize windows to half and half (or whatever configuration) with keyboard shortcuts. What do you think makes the tiling approach better than that?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:49
    I could get 80% of the way there on macos, but had to abandon it.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:47
    it's not usually corners that matter, I guess :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:47
    would prefer to make the window smaller and make more room for something else
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:46
    if there is information that can get hidden, then I don't want to see it at all
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:46
    I don't want it stacked, since I want to see everything in a logical chunk, not overlapping windows.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:46
    Yeah, I use macOS with its default window manager, and I have different workspaces with different apps, etc...
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:45
    so, workspace 1 is all my comms and browsers, 2 is emacs and some terminals, 4 is VS code and some terminals for C# right now, 10 is where I dismiss terminals I don't actually want to read, like launching some UI with logs in the background.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:45
    Thanks for the answer! Do you any of the feature you're describing necessitate tiling windows? When I read through the advantages they all seem like they would work fine with a stacking window manager?
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:40
    I especially like it when I am working on different projects that require different tooling and IDEs. Some emacs users try to use emacs for absolutely everything including window-management for similar reasons.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:38
    and organizing things in familiar places wrt multiple monitors so I can get to them quickly.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:37
    I don't think I often change window sizes. I move things around workspaces, make one fullscreen (this slack is now), put it back in its spot, so it's more about overview vs focus, if that makes sense.
    # Gary Trakhman 2019-08-27 08:36
    I am stuck on i3 and never really customized it after the first 2 weeks of 4 years. Using the keyboard and switching tasks/context save time for me.
    # Roben Kleene 2019-08-27 08:35
    Any fans of tiling window managers here? That's tiling window managers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiling_window_manager) in contrast to stacking window managers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stacking_window_manager). I've read a bunch from people who love using them around online. But I haven't found anyone who can convincingly describe why they prefer them. Most people talk about how they are easier to control from the keyboard, but that seems to stem from them being customizable, not from them tiling windows. I.e., what differentiates a tiling window manager is that for example if you have two windows next to each other, and you make one of them larger, it will simultaneously make the other one smaller. I'd love to hear from people who prefer tiling windows over stacking windows what they consider the advantages to be.

    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-23 23:49
    Nushell is extremely powerful. I would call this a domain specific language focused on file manipulation. Red's parse module is i think even more power than nushell. That's the best part of Red. I once used Icon to do something that no other language could do, as it has backtracking which is very tricky stuff. Probably the hardest programming one can do short of LISP.
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-08-23 20:27

    # William Taysom 2019-08-23 19:29
    Insert > Table
    # Edward de Jong 2019-08-23 13:28
    Excel has a full programming language embedded inside. Because excel hides formulas and code, and shows data (the opposite of most programming environments) it is not surprising that many people think it isn't a programming language. But having been a business automation consultant and walked into companies who had a crazy quilt of automation, it was almost guaranteed that some critical business process was automated inside Excel. It is a very robust tool, extremely well tested, and i have only caught Excel in an error once. The latest versions of Excel can go to about a million rows before it chokes and dies. That is a lot of records! I call it the poor man's database system.
    # nicolas decoster 2019-08-23 03:02
    Somewhere else in this slack people discuss if Excel is a general purpose programming tool. Meanwhile, somewhere else in Internet, someone develops a ray tracer with Excel! :slightly_smiling_face: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m28jJ7CMp8A

    # Doug Moen 2019-07-05 15:06
    I've never seen anything like this in an ACM conference. I know it looks like a prank, but I think that there are core ideas in the paper that can be taken seriously, once you decode the jargon. Consider Ubuntu and Smalltalk. Both are technically "open source", but Ubuntu is neoliberal, and Smalltalk is anarchist. In Ubuntu, although you technically can get access to the source, you need to use the CLI to install source packages, and then you need a huge amount of technical expertise to make changes to the source, build new versions of the software, and install your modified programs. And then you are in trouble if you want to update. It's neoliberal because of the power imbalance between the user and the corporate structure that controls the source. In Smalltalk, all of the source code for the system you are running is instantly available, you can easily make small changes just by editing some text, and then you can immediately see the effects of your changes within a running system. The user has much more power and autonomy in a Smalltalk system: it is an anarchist approach to open source.
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-07-05 13:32
    Can anybody here shed light on what's going on in this paper?

    https://ironholds.org/resources/papers/anarchist_hci.pdf
    3 comments
    # Prathyush 2019-07-04 05:21
    This is kind of a sanity check / knowledge representation question thats been bothering me for quite some time now. Whenever I end up modelling systems on a big scale, I end up drawing things like. So this is like layers of the system with each layer containing subsystems that can be layered or are graphs in themselves. Now these entities are in flux in that they change their topology as time progresses. This is the biggest model I can conjure up to visually articulate my conceptual understanding of most systems.

    My question is, are these the natural concepts to represent complex systems or are there simpler fundamental units that can be composed to build bigger systems that generate the desired system dynamics? Have you guys come across anything in the literature? I have this inkling that graphs . could probably be expressed with some sort of simple units of composition.
    9 comments

    # Stefan Lesser 2019-06-28 05:27
    A young aspiring programmer asks you as an expert and mentor:
    >"I want to understand the most important programming paradigms and learn about the broadest set of language features out there. What is the minimal set of programming languages I should look at? Popularity and how widely used these languages are doesn't matter, I just want the highest :exploding_head:::nerd_face: ratio to maximize my learning."

    Here's what I think:
    • C — for a simple, pragmatic, influential, and still widely used procedural language and to understand memory management
    • Smalltalk — for a highly dynamic language and environment, message passing and the origins of OOP
    • Lisp — because you wouldn't take me seriously if I left it off such a list
    • Haskell — for a pure functional, strongly typed language with laziness and strong compiler support (error checking, synthesis, etc.)
    • Forth — for an even simpler, but still highly expressive, extensible, and dynamic language
    • Datalog — for logic programming and constraint solvers (or maybe Prolog instead?)
    • Erlang — for actor model and concurrent programming

    What would you respond?
    14 comments
    # Dan Cook 2019-06-22 08:43

    1 comments
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-06-18 00:14
    >>> Enter TurboEditor. Because of this one simple little thing (not so little actually) that my friend found, we were able to decompile the entire CanDo program and figure out how it worked. Remember that important thing? Yes, that’s right, CanDo is actually written in itself and it could actually modify pieces that are currently executing. Let me clarify this just a little. One card could modify another card, then pull that card into focus. The actual card wasn’t currently executing, but the deck was. In fact, we came to find that CanDo was merely a facade. We also found that there was a very powerful object oriented, fully reentrant, self-modifying, programming language under that facade of a UI. In fact, this is how CanDo’s UI worked. Internally, it could take an element, decompile it, modify it and then recompile it right away and make it go live, immediately adding the updated functionality to a button or slider.

    >While CanDo could modify itself, it never did this. Instead, it utilized a parent-child relationship. It always created a child sandbox for user-created decks. This sandbox area is where the user built new CanDo Decks. Using this sandbox approach, this is how CanDo built and displayed a preview of your deck’s window. The sandbox would then be saved to a deck file and then executed as necessary.
    1 comments
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-06-18 00:13
    >>> A programmer friend who was working towards his CompSci masters owned an Amiga, and also owned CanDo. In fact, he introduced me to it. He had been poking around with CanDo and found that it supported three very interesting functions. It had the ability to decompile its own code into humanly readable format to allow modification, syntactically check the changes and recompile it, all while still running. Yes, you read that right. It supported on-the-fly code modification. Remember this, it’s important.
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-06-18 00:12
    https://www.google.com/amp/s/randocity.com/2018/03/27/cando-an-amiga-programming-language/amp/ more in the same vein: tales of an extinct amiga-based successor to hypercard that may have been secretly written as a sort of smalltalk-image-type-thing?!

    # Yoz Grahame 2019-06-11 11:54
    A separate thread based on @Daniel Hines’s comment 1560278176.045100.html#1560278279.045900

    I’ve thought about WinFS on and off for years, often hearing the same refrain from others who yearn for what WinFS might have been. And now I’m turning on it: if a filesystem-level database was that good an idea, we’d have it already. I’m being deliberately provocative here because I genuinely want to know what problems WinFS could have solved that
    1. aren’t just as solvable at app/userspace level (sorry, I’m not an OS expert)
    2. are based on what we know of WinFS’s actual API and capabilities, rather than capabilities of other databases that we wish a filesystem would have. (I’m also interested in apps using other databasey filesystem features, but it’s a slightly different discussion)
    35 comments

    # Yoz Grahame 2019-06-03 16:33
    One of the things that hit me in the SwiftUI XCode demo (in the opening keynote, not PSOTU): at the very beginning, he clicks the rendered “Hello world” widget in the simulator panel; XCode focuses the editor panel and highlights the code for the widget instance in question. It’s blink-and-you’ll-miss-it fast, and the audience don’t react at all.

    I’d like to know: which existing web framework + IDE combos currently do this? Specifically: click a rendered component in a page (in a browser, or browser preview panel) and be taken to the code that instantiates that component?
    20 comments

    In Unix, everything is a file. This is often viewed as a positive, but it's often a poor abstraction for many things. This discussion goes into some of the issues.

    # Stefan Lesser 2019-05-23 08:56
    Or you could see Unicode as a case study of how to build and maintain an international, cultural, technological building block that enables communication across cultures and deals with the challenges that come with it. Including complexities introduced when actively trying to deal with diversity and taking cultural bias out of a technology.
    2 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-23 00:45
    Unicode exemplifies the tyranny of committees staffed with people who don't care how much damage they do as they erect their perfectly hypercomplex edifice. It started out nice, hey, let's stop overloading code points in the 256 char range. They quickly add a bunch of characters and things are okay, but then they continue to add more and more obscure alphabets, then they go off the rails are add the "astral" set of characters beyond UTF16, and turn it into an icon database, which changes every year, sure to break on older operating systems. Unicode was not designed to be an art database, yet that is their current intention, with multiple flavors of coloration as they make it more and more ridiculously complicated. I wish they would stop, or at least only revise it once every 10 years like the census.
    3 comments
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-05-22 14:04
    https://begriffs.com/posts/2019-05-23-unicode-icu.html

    “Puh-leaze, if your program can’t handle Medieval Irish carvings then I want nothing to do with it.“ :joy:
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-20 23:36
    I will remind people that the Luna people are going for a very hard target, which is having dual graphical + textual representation, freely convertible. Also, i added info on Jonathan Blow's Jai language, which i estimate will release in 2020. It is an extremely thorough implementation, designed for building games, and is already greatly superior to C++ IMHO in its current state. Of course we can only see videos at this point, but you can tell it is real, and coming.
    15 comments

    # Scott Anderson 2019-05-20 14:50
    Disclaimer: I work at Facebook on VR and have directly and indirectly been part of 3D interface conversations

    # Paul Biggar 2019-05-20 13:44
    @nicolas decoster Basically, we struggled at the intersection of “how does this language actually work” and “can people understand this”. An example of the former was “what is the lifecycle of a HTTP request that touches a DB”, and of the latter “can we make if (x % 5 == 0) easy to read, understand, and edit”

    @nicolas decoster Good to know. Will prioritize that one.

    # Paul Biggar 2019-05-20 13:24

    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:21
    Sean McDirmid used a symbol to indicate he wanted that value to be pinned and displayed
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:21
    you could do the "where your cursor is" + a pin action
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:20
    I think something along those lines is important
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:20
    yeah, we ended up with explicit watches where you told us what you wanted
    2 comments
    # Paul Biggar 2019-05-20 12:18
    One issue we’re having is choosing what “live values” to display. Right now we only show the value where the cursor is. We tried showing the “trace” of values through the function (ie for each line, statement, expr, whateve: show the value), but it ended up being super cluttered cause most of the values were larger than one line (long string, object/record with more than 1 field)
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:16
    Excited to see where you land with it
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:15
    Yeah, it's super cool you guys are headed in that direction. :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Paul Biggar 2019-05-20 12:14
    Dark’s debugging situation is very similar to lighttable in terms of UI. We designed the language to support this too, including making the language and values immutable, and automatically recording results of any impure fns called in production. In future, we’re planning on better sampling of production values (eg always tracking errors, and otherwise tracking “interesting” values), integrating fuzzing/quickcheck, integrating unit testing, adding visualizations (I think LT had/has this?).
    # Paul Biggar 2019-05-20 12:08
    @Chris Granger lol
    # Chris Granger 2019-05-20 12:00
    Sounds familiar :wink:
    # Shalabh 2019-05-20 11:54
    https://twitter.com/paulbiggar/status/1124831866052235264?s=19 via @Paul Biggar.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-20 00:53
    The reason Idris, et al, are woefully inadequate to provide executable specifications is that they contain neither a database model nor a graphical/interactive model. 90% of the code in games is related to tracking user interaction or drawing, and only a small part of any typical graphical interactive product could possibly be programmed in the academic tools. Since a lot of products have aesthetic aspects like ease of learning and use, that are every bit as important as calculating a sum correctly, i find every single proving system to be utterly useless in my day to day work. I want the computer to catch as many errors as possible, without inducing extra work.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-20 00:48
    To achieve maximum productivity, being able to execute the spec means you just saved an implementation phase that could easily deviate from the spec. So eliminating this step means a whole category of errors that can't happen. Also, it means you don't partially program the system in the spec phase then throw that work away. If such a thing can be done, it is a big win. In Modula-2 for example, each module consisted of 2 files, one was the DEFINITION part, which contained all externally visible (exported) items, which might be constants, types, functions, etc. and the IMPLEMENTATION module had the actual code for the definition. Thus it was possible by merely sending the tiny compiled DEFINITION file to another programmer, and they could build a system without a) seeing the implementation, or b) caring about the internals. The linker used a series of tricks to guarantee that the version you built against was up to date. This is decades ago, and still C++ doesn't have anything this elegant or simple, and the JS module system is a mediocre partial implementation of Modula-2's module system.

    In reality an executable spec is a slightly more detailed than ordinary spec, as one is combining what traditionally was done in two phases (and two separate documents) into one document. Still a big win, as a project development cycle would start with a concept, proceed to napkin spec, to data structure/algorithm design, to executable specification, and then alpha testing, beta testing, shipping. Also means that over time the changes to the product are kept synchronized with the spec. Who hasn't in their career faced the situation where the spec disagrees with the running product?, and in that situation, it is often unclear which should change. It is a well known fact that if you have sensors in a spacecraft, you better have an odd number, so you know by majority rule which one will be the source of truth. Reducing it to a single document IMHO is a really big win, and is the focus of my particular research.
    # Ian Bicking 2019-05-19 16:19
    In practice most places where I encounter a specification is when some aspect of a system has to be determined without constraining the entire implementation. For instance, two teams need to make two components that interact, the specification only defines the interaction, not the rest of the implementation. Or a product has certain requirements that must be communicated, a specification identifies those while allowing the implementors to use their discretion to define other aspects.

    In these cases it's deliberate and preferred that a specification can't be executed.

    When does someone want a specification that is equivalent to a program?
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-05-19 13:34
    eg Alabaster:
    Autocomplete Letting Apache Beam Applications Succeed Through Exploration Rapidly
    # Garth Goldwater 2019-05-19 13:34
    just found out about natural programming via the Jonathan Edwards episode of the podcast and I have to say the projects look very interesting but this research group also appears to be a lab for some of the most advanced bacronyms I've ever seen: https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~NatProg/
    # Daniel Hines 2019-05-19 11:27
    @magicmouse94937, if Idris and friends don’t meet your criteria for executable spec, what does?
    # Tudor Girba 2019-05-18 23:52
    Interesting to see the term executable specifications brought up. One of the major use cases for Glamorous Toolkit is exactly this one. We found that, like @magicmouse94937 is saying, we need a complete platform underneath combined with an expressive user interface. In our case, we use the Pharo language/runtime as the underlying platform.

    The idea of a specification is that it is simpler to understand than the real system. Now, if the specification is executable, what is the difference between that and a real system. Our answer is that there does not need to be one. However, various technical considerations might impose differences, such as having only certain languages supported in the target deployment environment. Even in this case, the specification can replace the documentation and can be traced to the actual implementation, too.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-18 21:51
    Idris is not an executable spec language. Idris has some features inherited from proof assistants, but is again a totally insufficient language in which to express visual concepts, much less access a database. If you only have a computational program, Coq, Idris, and all the academic languages look promising, but i find Academia's willful ignoring of the last 30 years of personal computer evolution, which is a steady progression towards full-on bitmap graphics and internet/database access to be puzzling, to the point of being annoying.
    # Daniel Hines 2019-05-17 13:51
    Idris is in this space, right?
    # Daniel Hines 2019-05-17 13:50
    Can you expound what an “executable spec” looks like? What technology would that be? (Don’t say Haskell :face_with_rolling_eyes: )
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-17 13:41
    One of the features of some next-gen projects is to eliminate the need for techniques like TLA+ and UML. The concept is to make the specification the final code, and skip the implementation phase. Since TLA+ and UML do not produce a final product you have then the errors related to mapping those into executable code. In my own work i go from sketch, to data structure design, to executable spec which is the final product. I believe that is the shortest way to the goal.
    2 comments

    # Dan Cook 2019-05-08 10:13
    Two thoughts on that idea:

    1.The idea of blurring the line between interaction and programming, but applied to interconnected devices. E.g. ability to grab hold of the sequence of events (the call comes when music is playing, and you silence the music and/or redirect the call), and make it a "function" that's triggered on those events.

    2. http://worrydream.com/MagicInk/#engineering_inference_from_the_environment

    3. Maybe a combination: I noticed that you always do x and y when a call comes and your music is playing. Do you want me to do that for you automatically next time?
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-05-08 06:14
    one step further, that shouldn't be a feature to implement at all, there should be a way to say "when a call is accepted in my phone and I'm in the same room as one of my speakers pause the music of those speakers and ask me if I want to put the call on those speakers"
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-05-08 06:11
    instead of getting the notice from her phone to the speaker that there's a call, she has to actively tell the speaker, because for the speaker team it was easier to detect a gesture in 3D than to integrate a feature with android
    # Mariano Guerra 2019-05-08 06:11
    it's kind of Conway's law but for features: organizations which design systems ... are constrained to produce designs which are copies of the communication structures of these organizations.
    # Felix Kohlgrüber 2019-05-08 05:48
    Seems like most people aren't seeing the "bigger picture" and therefore just achieve local maxima. At Google IO yesterday they showed that their new smart speaker thing can pause music when you make a certain gesture (https://youtu.be/lyRPyRKHO8M?t=4604). In the video, the woman gets called on her smartphone and then uses a gesture to pause the music. Probably better than a voice command, but they won't get my applause until they either forward the call to the smart speaker or reduce music volume automatically when the smartphone gets called. It's 2019 and two devices used by the same person in the same room still can't cooperate on something like this. That's kind of embarrassing, isn't it?
    Anyway, the crowd seemed to love it...

    # Nick Smith 2019-05-08 02:50

    # nicolas decoster 2019-05-08 01:35
    That is why I think one way to design a "better" programming experience, is to not target existing programmers, but new incoming programmers with a fresh creative mind. Existing/professionnal programmers will follow next if the designed new programming experience is efficient in regard to their buisness. So target children and hobbyists first, make them have fun and ensure programming is easy for them (yet "serious" programming). And better: let's those new creative minds bring their ideas of a better way to do programming.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-05-07 22:13
    If you ask people what kind of eating utensil they wish they had, they can't imagine anything but what they know; it takes a genius to invent the spork, the trong, and the splayd. If you ask people to imagine a color they haven't seen, they can't. Invention is not primarily driven by minor improvements. Small improvements are the realm of the engineer, which is a very conservative profession. I foolishly attended an engineering school, when i would have been happier in a science-oriented university. The training of engineers is primarily negative: they see what failed, and avoid it, using safe-for-deployment proven methods. Really quite opposite in their fundamental attitudes about change. The artist/inventor boldly goes where nobody imagines, and often suffers greatly because people reject things oftentimes when it is too far from their current experience. For example, I was one of a lucky few students who attended a talk by John Backus, the inventor of FORTRAN, about his new Functional language, and when he told the professors in attendance that you couldn't update a variable they were shocked and leaving the room all shook their heads and exclaimed he was a madman. Fast forward to now and everyone and their brother is talking about functional languages. As the old Panasonic slogan goes "slightly ahead of our time", it is far more lucrative to be slightly ahead than way ahead!
    1 comments
    # Corey Montella 2019-05-07 19:32
    > Could also be that these people are focussed on the first order problem they need to solve for their job/hobby/study

    I might give you that if this subreddit were't filled with hobbyist programming language designers!
    # Ivan Reese 2019-05-07 13:26
    Could also be that these people are focussed on the first order problem they need to solve for their job/hobby/study, and are not in the position to zoom out and think broadly, or are not aware of the broad range of possibilities.

    I mean, we all fancy ourselves imagineers, but none of us are actually entertaining ideas like “do what I mean not what I say, perfectly” because we know how damned impossible that’d be to build. We’re all focussed on what we think we can actually build. Safe to assume they are too.

    # Mariano Guerra 2019-03-21 02:20
    random rant: we talk about end user programming, but we don't even have programmers programming for most tasks, I wanted to save all the links from a page as pdfs to read them offline while I travel, the reason I save them as pdfs is that the style of the pages looks really bad (small text, really long lines, no margins or paddings) and saving them as pdfs makes them readable, saving them to pocket doesn't fix it either. So I have to long press each link, open in new tab, then switch tab, select menu, page > download as pdf, close tab, for each link (more than 20), then I go to the file manager, I can't figure out the gesture to select a range (click, shift click on a laptop, I'm on the tablet I will take on the trip), I select each item manually, select share to google drive so that they appear on my cellphone too. either the file manager or google drive decides to upload all the files with the title "Untitled", not the filename, not the pdf title metadata, just Untitled. There's no way I, a programmer, can automate any of this, neither can I discover if there's a feature or gesture I need in the applications I'm using. Where I'm going is that a closer objetive may be an "advanced mode" for applications, it doesn't have to be easy to start, but at least it has to be possible, we are not even there :confused:
    9 comments

    # Ivan Reese 2019-03-13 17:44

    # Ivan Reese 2019-03-13 17:43
    I'm fine with the lack of specificity around #random. It's a good pressure relief for concerns about whether something is duly on-topic for #general, or might be too much of a distraction despite still being more broadly interesting.
    # Scott Anderson 2019-03-13 15:42
    maybe archive #random and use #general?
    # Scott Anderson 2019-03-13 15:41
    random has a lot of good conversations directly or tangentially related to Future of Coding. I agree that #off-topic is a better choice than random, but most of the posts in #random are on topic that don't fit into specific channels, what's a better name for that than random?
    # Stefan Lesser 2019-03-13 15:26
    The differences between #general and #random are very subtle and frankly I don’t really understand what qualifies for which one. Also, if I recall correctly, that's just the channels each new Slack starts with by default, so it's not that we have them for a really good reason. Many other communities have an #off-topic channel instead, which I think makes it a little easier to distinguish between what goes where.
    # Jake Brownson 2019-03-11 14:42
    In our work slack "general" is for general, but work-focused things, "random" is for sharing cute pets/memes, etc
    # Felix Kohlgrüber 2019-03-11 13:47
    It isn't easy to draw a line, but I think having both "general" and "random" does make sense. I post stuff to "general" when I think it's interesting for most people and also worth their time. For things that aren't as relevant / practical / ... I post to "random". In other words, I'd say that "general" is for stuff that other's shouldn't miss and "random" is for the rest. I wouldn't mind if "random" was high traffic because I just skim over it most of the time. I follow "general" more closely.

    # Kartik Agaram 2019-03-11 13:07
    Really cool paper, @Felix Kohlgrüber. Worth posting to #general considering the recent conversations here on structured editing. The authors are pointing out a new trade-off between conventional and structured editors that I hadn't seen before.
    1 comments
    # Felix Kohlgrüber 2019-03-11 12:21
    > “Syntax highlighting” is an unfortunate misnomer, since pattern matching is considerably weaker than syntactic analysis. It would be more accurate to call it “unreliable keyword, string, and comment recognition”.
    From https://www.researchgate.net/publication/258629476_Displaying_and_Editing_Source_Code_in_Software_Engineering_Environments

    # Jake Brownson 2019-03-09 23:56
    @David Piepgrass Sorry to hear about that. I think I've been on both sides of this sort of thing. Sometimes it's hard to articulate exactly why it's not meshing with a particular personality and you just gotta make a decision and move forward even if you can't 100% justify it. Would you say you approach your professional work with the attitude that you're there to take the things that are important to your employer/boss and make them important to you even if it isn't clear why they're important to your employer?
    3 comments
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-03-09 17:19
    Groups of humans are on some level still just troops of hominids on the savannah. There are many ways to not fit in, and the penalty for not fitting in is the same (being cast out), and the group doesn't really have good self-awareness of where the misfit lay. And why does it have to be you that needs to change and needs feedback?

    The good news is that there's one major way we aren't like hominids on the savannah: there are lots of groups out there, in dazzling varieties. Just forget the experience, stop trying to learn from it, find another group to join.

    (And another, and another, and another. Some people have a better fit with the larger population than others. But the strategy doesn't change. Try to forget the past, and treat each new group as the first.)
    # Edward de Jong 2019-03-09 17:06
    well, in today's world, the HR dept has instructed people never to tell people who are being fired why they were fired, for fear it could backfire in some lawsuit. I find it very lamentable, because it deprives the person being fired of getting very important feedback. I prefer although it is completely out of style, to tell the person to their face exactly why they are so disagreeable or their work habits so objectionable that they must be sacked. Being fired has catapulted many people into fantastic success, as it is such a shock to the system that you can suddenly reinvent yourself. As my father Hamilton used to say, you never know where your help is coming from Of the three guys who used to do the Top Gear show, one of them James May had been fired from a series of jobs. He is now one of the most famous, and beloved, TV personalities in the world. I suspect if you ask a co-worker over a glass of beer they might tell you the real reason. People who row too fast in the boat definitely can cause fear for the slower-rowing people, so maybe you just picked too mediocre a company, and need to find one of the places where people can really throw themselves into their job and do great things.
    # David Piepgrass 2019-03-09 15:51
    Okay guys, I am sick of being told I'm "bright" or "clever" or "smart"... just before I am turned down for a job or, in the case of what happened to me two days ago, fired.

    I suspect that the kind of people who don't like me are the same kind of people who are unwilling to explain to my face why they don't like me. Come to think of it, I guess that's just how human culture typically works? But it hurts at lot. So when I was "laid off" (their words, but I was definitely fired), I was completely shocked. They briefly explained why, but it went over my head and I immediately forgot the words in the sentences. Something about cultural differences? About how the work environment is "chaotic" and my organized, perfectionist style was not acceptable? I sent an email yesterday morning at 3AM saying "So, respectfully, may I have the explanation repeated?" but as of yet, no response. One thing I did vaguely remember was what the company's figurehead-leader-of-the-Canadian-subsidiary (not involved in the decision) said something like "we're looking for people that put in 85% effort, and people that give 110% don't really fit in." Hmm, that's probably not exactly how it was worded, but all I can remember with certainty is the numbers 85% (describing a typical/ideal employee) and 110% (me).

    Oh well, theoretically that should mean I can look for developer tools jobs to my heart's content... but for the moment I'm too exhausted, owing to a sudden difficulty sleeping.
    1 comments

    # Janne Aukia 2019-02-08 03:07
    I realized yesterday how similar Observable notebooks are to visual (graph based) programming: in Observable, any time you change a value somewhere, all references using it update reactively.

    https://beta.observablehq.com/@mbostock/how-observable-runs
    https://twitter.com/jaukia/status/1093571831607513089

    Interesting how different UIs for same level of programming abstraction lead to quite different UX.

    # Ivan Reese 2019-02-01 13:04
    There's a game that came out a handful of years ago, that is based on these sorts of non-euclidean spaces (and all sorts of other tricks), using the same implementation (portal rendering).     # Ivan Reese 2019-02-01 13:04

    # Duncan Woods 2019-02-01 03:08
    @Ivan Reese for 3d interfaces, something I find fascinating are non-euclidean spaces (I guess they are not 3d anymore lol). I think they have profound scope for representing multi-dimensional computational concepts yet still being tactile and intuitive. There are not nearly as abstract and mathematical as they sound.

    Take a look at this awesome video. I love
    - walking up a hill both ways
    - the bit at 2:40 where walking through a tunnel makes you smaller alice and wonderland style. This is not representing computation this is experiencing computation from a first person perspective operating on your own perception
    - the room totally convinces me - it's feels so natural despite being non-euclidean

    Mind blowing:

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kEB11PQ9Eo8

    # Mariano Guerra 2019-01-29 02:07
    So, yesterday was the second time I met online with a relative to help him with some physics problems he was studying for an entrance exam to the university. our solution was to share photos of books and notes on paper, to share sound recording and at the end we did a video call where he shared the book and pointed with his finger and I explained to him with my voice since it's hard to write and focus with a phone. Just a long way of saying, "the computer as a free form expression medium hasn't happened yet"

    Hi all, apologies if this is a bit random. I’m struggling a bit with motivation.

    # Janne Aukia 2019-01-02 04:23
    Pico-8 is a cute little thing. On the web site, it is said to be a "fantasy console". It includes a minimal Lua, graphics editor + sound + music editor. "Cartridges" are shared as PNG images with the code embedded in the image. You can inspect code of any cartridge. You can even run it on a Raspberry Pi and use I/O to interact with sensors, motors, etc. Fans of C64/Amiga, or HyperCard, might appreciate.

    Some things that might be interesting in terms of future or coding:
    - a small API that you can remember makes things fun
    - constraints can invoke creativity
    - how you call something, in this case "fantasy console", matters
    - community, and learning, is important when building dev tools

    Pico-8:
    https://www.lexaloffle.com/pico-8.php

    A presentation from the creator of Pico-8:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=87jfTIWosBw

    There is also a prototype tool by Gabriel Florit, which combines Pico-8 with Bret Victor -style live coding and time scrubbing: https://script-8.github.io
    19 comments
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-12-21 15:18
    I'm feeling bad about going massively off-topic at ../thinking-together/1545387390.005400.html#1545412360.017100 and below. Particularly since Slack threads are flat. So I'll demote myself here at #random.

    This is super resonant to me:

    "For twenty years, we’ve been making corporations rich by buying into standardization and scale — making it feasible for them to funnel us into silos. We can stop this process, and perhaps even reverse it.. Personal software should be personal: it should not scale or conform; it should chafe at strictures the same way you do, and burst out of any box that dare enclose it." -- John Ohno (http://www.lord-enki.net/medium-backup/2018-12-21_Free-software-and-the-revolt-against-transactionality-3a44a1b7f96d.html)

    (/cc @Antranig Basman in case this side was one of the things you wanted to reply to in the earlier thread.)
    3 comments
    # Jonathan Conway 2018-12-21 10:18
    Recurring thought I’ve been having:
    The tools I most rely on organise my workspace in lists. ≡
    I sometimes wish they could instead organise it in graphs. ፨

    Examples:
    • The text editor organises my code into lines.
    • The file system organises my files in lists of files within hierarchical folders.
    • The task tracker organises my tasks into categorised lists.

    The list ordering is often tedious and inefficient to navigate. It forces me to switch back and forth rapidly between vastly separated areas, either with my eyes or with my eyes and mouse/keyboard. It’s tricky or impossible to get a view of all the elements I am working with at the same time.

    When in “designer-mode” I often resort to diagramming (either paper or virtual). A diagram lets me position the elements the way I’m actually thinking about them, with closely related elements close to eachother and less-related elements farther apart. If an element has several closely related elements, it’s easy to draw them adjactent to eachother, whereas this wouldn’t be possible if they had to be in a flat list.

    In an era of 3D virtual spaces and 3D printing, I find it ironic and aggravating that the typical programmer doesn’t even get a 2D, let alone 3D, view of their environment, but is still held down to 1D list-ual views! lol
    14 comments

    (a) What is the one thing you love the most and can’t live without?
    (b) What’s the one feature you miss so dearly that it keeps you looking for alternatives?
    (Can be something you saw somewhere else, or something you haven’t seen and just dream up.)

    Many years ago (over ten, I think), when I was very inspired by wikis, I put a couple of pages on the original wiki about the possibility of using wikis to develop software, or to give our IDEs wikilike (social, easy hyperlinking) etc. capabilities. It's been a long time since I looked at these pages, but they have grown a bit with contributions from other people in the community since then, and there are still some interesting thoughts there : http://wiki.c2.com/?ProgrammingInWiki , http://wiki.c2.com/?WikiIde

    # Gregg Tavares 2018-12-02 08:15
    Today I learned about site called "Un-code Mania" where "un" rhymes with "boon". It was a Japanese site where it's a pun because "unko" means "shit" so "un-code" was shit code. It was a site where you post code you think is crap and people shit :hankey:vote it. The more :hankey:votes the worse the code.

    Of course at first it sounds like a joke and it is, but, it also serves as a place to look at code people judge as bad and hopefully learn why it's bad.

    I'm only guessing the reason it is offline is that most people who want to post bad code probably saw that code at work and if they post it might get the site in trouble. Just a guess.

    Apparently you could also judge the code as "Hiyo-code" which is another pun as "Hiyoko" means baby chicken. Putting this mark meant code by a beginner but fixable.

    Anyway, it brought up interesting thoughts given it provides a chance to understand why some code is judged as bad
    1 comments

    # Guido Bartolucci 2018-11-20 06:23
    Since a bunch of us are going about this independently (no company backing us, no university affiliation) I'm wondering if you all have good suggestions for getting access to the materials that normal university researchers have access to. In particular I'm interested in research journals and libraries. We can of course join organizations like ACM and IEEE, and given that we aren't taking a salary for this work we can easily argue that we should get the student rate. But IEEE in particular is still pretty expensive. Your local university library is also a great resource and so far I've found that residents can walk through the stacks and in fact also borrow. But it's not the same as having a student id and accessing everything the university has to offer. Do any of you have any advice for indie researchers like myself?

    # Nikolas Martens 2018-11-15 14:01
    Quite impressied how fast this community is growing. Does anybody !here happen to be based in Berlin?
    # Vladimir Gordeev 2018-11-14 22:36
    Just realized that documentation usually describes higher level of abstraction about code. It describers into what layers program is split, or what functionality several applications should provide.

    There must be a tool that would parse plain English statements with links to your code, transform it into some constraints, and then apply these constraints while developing. This will connect documentation and code more tightly, reduce chance of being obsolete.

    Say you're writing in documentation that: "The whole application is split into three layers: A, B, C. A and C layers never communicate. A consists of ComponentA1, ComponentA2. Components in C layers are all located in 'c_layer' directory". A tool gonna parse it and produce rules:


    layer('A', 'ComponentA1').
    layer('A', 'ComponentA2').

    read_components_in_dir('C', "c_layer").

    io_allowed(Component1, Component2) :-
      layer('A', Component1), layer('C', Component2), false;
    io_allowed(Component1, Component2) :-
      layer('A', Component2), layer('C', Component1), false;
    io_allowed(Component1, Component2).


    I'm not sure I got the Prolog code right, but you get the idea.

    Thus it will throw a warning if it notices that code break constraint described in documentation.

    This will motivate programmers describe higher level assumptions about code in documentation, because it constraints it and provides some kind of safety. Just like static typing or assertion does.
    13 comments
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 13:25
    We also can embed various views of examples. Examples have assertions, like tests, but they also return the object. Combined with the fact that objects can have different facets and with the fact that we can embed these artifacts in a document, it becomes a highly effective mechanism. We have a simple example framework that replaces the testing framework and we now practice example-driven development.
    # Shalabh 2018-11-14 10:39
    GToolkit is doing going in this direction, it seems. E.g. you can have markdown like docs within which you embed live results of relevant queries on the code repository.
    # Felix Kohlgrüber 2018-11-14 10:38
    That's an interesting discussion! I'd be neat if more people would collaborate on documentation, and as @Stefan Lesser pointed out, novices to a project are especially important as collaborators.
    I wonder if more people would edit documentation if it wasn't owned by the project's owner. Think about having wikipedia-like editing right within your documentation. Especially if I'm new to a project, I'm always afraid to screw up other people's documentation by writing something stupid. I wonder if knowing that the next regular guy who reads my changes could easily improve or correct them would lower the bar to start collaborating.
    Another option could be to include comments into each documentation page. People are used to providing feedback if they can, so they would probably point out a lot of issues that could then be used by maintainers to improve documentation.
    Using current tools (IRC, github issues / PRs) all of this is possible already, but I think that making it easier and integrating it better into the documentation itself could make a huge difference.
    # Shalabh 2018-11-14 10:37
    There's the question of content (what should be written, what aspects covered). But there's also the problem of the representation medium - most documentation today is off to the side, completely disconnected from the artifacts it is talking about. This is a fundamentally fractured model. You not only have out of date stuff, but constantly jump back and forth. Instead of a clear distinction between 'docs' and 'code', ideally there would be a hypermedium with various views at different levels of detail: high level views (system design, narratives) all the way to low level views (code) - all of them interconnected and traversible.
    14 comments
    # Dylan Lederle-Ensign 2018-11-14 06:05
    explaining why a design or implementation choice was made
    # Nick Smith 2018-11-14 04:03
    Explaining what a function/method/class does :stuck_out_tongue:
    # Vladimir Gordeev 2018-11-14 02:26
    It seems like large amount of documentation could be generated if we had proper programming environments.
    Version incompatabilities, examples of usage, changes in API -- all of this can be generated.

    What else is left? Stories, grand narratives? Use cases?
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 02:03
    And here I am referring to any details about my system. I think everything about my system should be explainable to a newcomer in minutes
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 02:02
    Since about 15 years I am practicing demo-driven development. This means that I drive my development form the point of view of the demo that I will give with and about it. This forces me to build the story into the system, including the visuals.
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 02:01
    I do think that writing documentation can be fun if you have the right development experience for it
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 02:00
    Precisely
    # Stefan Lesser 2018-11-14 01:54
    It seems obvious that the person who knows most about the system needs to document it. However, it turns out good documentation often comes from other people, who had to understand the system from scratch long after it has been designed.

    It’s hard to look at our own creations with a Beginner’s Mind again, but that’s really helpful, if not essential, to write good documentation.

    And I’m not sure if writing documentation itself can be more fun — I’d like to think so. For sure though, there are people who like writing documentation. So it’s great if you have a chance to collaborate with those.
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 01:30
    I think literate programming is interesting, too. But, we should not limit storytelling to words. Live and visual interactions are too powerful to leave out :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Nick Smith 2018-11-14 01:21
    I think writing documentation would be really fun if we had the right tools to do good storytelling. That's why I'm excited about efforts toward literate programming.
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 00:05
    What I find interesting is telling a story about and with the system I am building. To do that I am forced to build the story in the system. This often leads to visualizations that describe internal aspects, and this leads to live documentation.
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-14 00:05
    Documentation does not have to be tiresome to maintain :slightly_smiling_face:
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-11-13 13:18
    ---
    On a separate note, I did a brief analysis this morning of just how much GNU cat (and therefore GNU) sucks: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=18436735#18438344
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-11-13 13:12
    Yeah, I should elaborate. Well-written documentation can be great for collaboration. But well-written documentation can be really hard to do, even when the incentives are perfectly aligned (very rare even in open source; the world is complex). So lately I try to at least talk about the thing right in front of the thing rather than on some other page all by itself. That way at least if I screw up how I describe the thing, at least the reader has a chance at trying to cross-triangulate what I mean by looking at and running the thing itself.

    But you're a Smalltalk guy. I suspect I'm preaching to the choir :slightly_smiling_face:
    1 comments
    # Tudor Girba 2018-11-13 12:50
    interesting. I think interesting documentation can be conducive to collaboration.
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-11-13 10:23
    And all the up-front design really discourages collaboration. If the next person can't make any improvements, they have no opportunity to make it their own. This is where compatibility really kills you. Either you have to get it right up front, or you get stuck supporting crap. Either way: no collaboration.
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-11-13 10:21
    Documentation is a lousy way to foster collaboration.
    # Kartik Agaram 2018-11-13 10:18
    Then again, not one word in all that about collaboration, or working together with someone. That leaves a lot of fun on the table: https://plforums.org/practice/minimal-features-required-for-an-extensible-language#post_65

    And the Forth libraries I've seen don't really follow step 10 about documentation.
